I have gone over your-*proposal. Here follows my comment.
I am for much more extensive research on the various types of media,
their grammar and syntax.
Commentary on the non-discursive character of pictorial materials has
been well done by Susanne Langer in "Philosophy in a New Key." You
will see the key arguments presented in chapter 4 titled, "Discursive
and Presentational Forms" with especially pertinent material on pages 76,
77 and 78. She makes the point on page 77 that "photography, therefore,
has no vocabulary."
I believe that photographic specialists would deny this, but it is certainly
true that many of these experiences are of relatively instantaneous wholes
rather than of additive parts.
This has long been true, however. One has merely to think of a savage
or anyone else faced with non-discur sive situations. He had to take them
all in at once, so we have been doing this for a long, long time. True,
motion pictures and television have forced us to think harder about it, and
it is true that they themselves are more symbolic than the real life exper¬
ience. But I do not see anything essentially new in what has happened.
Most experiences, whether television or photographs, have an accompany¬
ing verbalism. Really we have very few audio visual experiences. They
are really verbal-audio visual experiences. Even a visit to a museum is
often aided by some kind of catalogue which describes. I realize this is
not the basic experience, but nevertheless this is true. We classify, we
name, and certainly this has a linear quality.
I think we need more carefully controlled, laboratory experience on this topic.
I don't see the value of a survey of the type you have outlined.
